review: This is great for anyone with amazon prime. This is hands down the easiest interface to navigate the amazon on demand content. Everything else works well, also, but the main page navigation is not always easy. It can be a bit overwhelming at times and make the screen feel crowded.If you're a PLEX user, plan to plop down a solid $5 for the app. I have never had to pay for plex on any of my other devices. The cost of plex and the clunky home screen bring the rating down to a 4. I would have loved to give it a 5 but I just can't.

review: I have to be honest, I was a little skeptical about this thing but I was able to get if for less than $20 with Prime so I thought I couldn't lose and I was in the market for another Roku.It was a little finicky when I first started it up.  It tried to upgrade the software several times before completing successfully.  I suspect since I was part of the first wave to receive this, the Amazon servers were overwhelmed with requests.  Once I made it through the upgrade process, set up was a breeze.  It instantly recognized my networks and I was able to quickly get online.  Set up for Amazon Prime was automatic so nothing more to do there.  Set up for Netflix was the usual setup and was quick to complete.The device definitely is Amazon Prime-centric.  All you Amazon content is visible on the Home screen but it also works very well with Netflix.  The picture and sound quality has also been very good.  Fire TV is my go to device for watching any Amazon content, movie and music are both covered.Navigation is easy but I have found the companion app from the Google Play store to be disappointing.  The navigation from the phone is from a touch pad interface and it is very touchy, almost unusable.  Navigating with the included remote, however, is very easy.Not sure if this will be a true Roku killer (since it is missing HBO Go, which starting in April will be a stand alone option, not requiring an HBO subscription) but it comes pretty close.  I would definitely recommend over ChromeCast since it has its own remote control and does not require an Android device to operate.

review: I was torn between the Roku, Google and Amazon versions of what is (essentially) the same product. The streaming quality exceed that of Netflix using wireless (Netflix on my Samsung Smart TV looks pretty grainy over wireless), and I have access to Amazon Prime Instant Video, which rules.
